sentences.sentence: )On Tuesday morning, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will announce this year's Oscar nominees.

While the sameness of awards season often makes the nominations themselves utterly predictable, debating who ᅳ or what ᅳ should be nominated can surface unexpected hilarity and deserving brilliance.This year, The Point asked the staff of Times Opinion to share what was worthy of those strapping golden statuettes.

Here are the nominees.Vanessa Mobley, Op-Ed EditorI'll start by nominating Adam Driver in “Ferrari.” Not since Al Pacino in “Carlito's Way” have I seen an actor eat and really command a table in that way.Cornelia Channing, Editorial AssistantThis is not a minority opinion, but Emma Stone's thrilling performance in “Poor Things” transformed a character who could easily have been a caricature into something far more surprising.Yvonne Ashley Kouadjo, Op-Docs ProducerI'm still thinking about the incredible performances by Hinata Hiiragi and Soya Kurokawa, the child actors in Hirokazu Kore-eda's “Monster.”Valerie Pavilonis, Editorial AssistantGreta Lee was subtle and stunning in “Past Lives.”Rollin Hu, ResearcherGive an Oscar to Greta Lee's eyebrows.

Their performance wrecked me.Jessica Grose, WriterI loved the three main characters in “The Holdovers,” but I especially loved Da'Vine Joy Randolph's performance, which was just such a full depiction of grief while still being funny.Taylor Maggiacomo, Graphics EditorI love a good teen-star-to-Oscar-nomination pipeline.

Charles Melton's portrayal of a man who was robbed of his childhood in “May December” was such a standout.Madi Winfield, Editorial AssistantAnimated films don't receive acting nominations, but Robert Pattinson's performance in “The Boy and the Heron” is riveting and disarming in the best ways.Jillian Weinberger, Senior Producer, Opinion AudioI loved Sandra Hüller's subtly complex performance in “Anatomy of a Fall.”Annie-Rose Strasser, Executive Producer, Opinion AudioCan someone be nominated twice for two movies?
Hüller's physical performance in “Zone of Interest” was striking, too.That movie also had the most upsetting sound design I've ever experienced in my life.

As the filmmakerhas said, “Zone” is really two movies ᅳ the one you see and the one you hear.Christopher Orr, Editor“Maestro” proves that “A Star Is Born” was no accident: Bradley Cooper is an astonishingly gifted director.

Don't pretend you saw this coming when he was just an actor typecast as sleazy best friends and boyfriends.Parker Richards, Staff EditorNo film represents the insanity, multipolarity and addled gumption of our era quite like “Cocaine Bear.” For topicality alone, it should be nominated for best picture.Anna Marks, Staff EditorWas there anything more delightful last year than “Bottoms”?
If the Academy had any sense, it would at least take this opportunity to contribute to Ayo Edebiri's inevitableEGOT.
)Lindsay Crouse, Senior Staff EditorGive Barry Keoghan every statue.

Whatever was going on in that bathtub in “Saltburn” is exactly the kind of emotive ingenuity the Academy was designed to recognize.Patrick Healy, Deputy Editor, OpinionAlso in “Saltburn,” Rosamund Pike's blithe to-the-manor-born line readings and asides make for a delicious Oscar pudding.Adam Sternbergh, Opinion Culture Editor“Murder on the Dancefloor” in “Saltburn.” Oscar for best song.
I don't care about eligibility rules.

Make this happen.Vanessa Mobley, Op-Ed Editor Cornelia Channing, Editorial Assistant Yvonne Ashley Kouadjo, Op-Docs Producer Valerie Pavilonis, Editorial Assistant Rollin Hu, Researcher Jessica Grose, Writer Taylor Maggiacomo, Graphics Editor Madi Winfield, Editorial Assistant Jillian Weinberger, Senior Producer, Opinion Audio Annie-Rose Strasser, Executive Producer, Opinion Audio Christopher Orr, Editor Parker Richards, Staff Editor Anna Marks, Staff Editor Lindsay Crouse, Senior Staff Editor Patrick Healy, Deputy Editor, Opinion Adam Sternbergh, Opinion Culture EditorPHOTO: (PHOTOGRAPH BY Amazon Studios FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: (Did you see “Saltburn”? Did you?)On Tuesday morning, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will announce this year’s Oscar nominees. While the sameness of awards season often makes the nominations themselves utterly predictable, debating who — or what — should be nominated can surface unexpected hilarity and deserving brilliance.This year, The Point asked the staff of Times Opinion to share what was worthy of those strapping golden statuettes. Here are the nominees.Vanessa Mobley, Op-Ed EditorI’ll start by nominating Adam Driver in “Ferrari.” Not since Al Pacino in “Carlito’s Way” have I seen an actor eat and really command a table in that way.Cornelia Channing, Editorial AssistantThis is not a minority opinion, but Emma Stone’s thrilling performance in “Poor Things” transformed a character who could easily have been a caricature into something far more surprising.Yvonne Ashley Kouadjo, Op-Docs ProducerI’m still thinking about the incredible performances by Hinata Hiiragi and Soya Kurokawa, the child actors in Hirokazu Kore-eda’s “Monster.”Valerie Pavilonis, Editorial AssistantGreta Lee was subtle and stunning in “Past Lives.”Rollin Hu, ResearcherGive an Oscar to Greta Lee’s eyebrows. Their performance wrecked me.Jessica Grose, WriterI loved the three main characters in “The Holdovers,” but I especially loved Da’Vine Joy Randolph’s performance, which was just such a full depiction of grief while still being funny.Taylor Maggiacomo, Graphics EditorI love a good teen-star-to-Oscar-nomination pipeline. Charles Melton’s portrayal of a man who was robbed of his childhood in “May December” was such a standout.Madi Winfield, Editorial AssistantAnimated films don’t receive acting nominations, but Robert Pattinson’s performance in “The Boy and the Heron” is riveting and disarming in the best ways.Jillian Weinberger, Senior Producer, Opinion AudioI loved Sandra Hüller’s subtly complex performance in “Anatomy of a Fall.”Annie-Rose Strasser, Executive Producer, Opinion AudioCan someone be nominated twice for two movies? Hüller’s physical performance in “Zone of Interest” was striking, too.That movie also had the most upsetting sound design I’ve ever experienced in my life. As the filmmakerhas said, “Zone” is really two movies — the one you see and the one you hear.Christopher Orr, Editor“Maestro” proves that “A Star Is Born” was no accident: Bradley Cooper is an astonishingly gifted director. Don’t pretend you saw this coming when he was just an actor typecast as sleazy best friends and boyfriends.Parker Richards, Staff EditorNo film represents the insanity, multipolarity and addled gumption of our era quite like “Cocaine Bear.” For topicality alone, it should be nominated for best picture.Anna Marks, Staff EditorWas there anything more delightful last year than “Bottoms”? If the Academy had any sense, it would at least take this opportunity to contribute to Ayo Edebiri’s inevitableEGOT.(Spoiler … it does not.)Lindsay Crouse, Senior Staff EditorGive Barry Keoghan every statue. Whatever was going on in that bathtub in “Saltburn” is exactly the kind of emotive ingenuity the Academy was designed to recognize.Patrick Healy, Deputy Editor, OpinionAlso in “Saltburn,” Rosamund Pike’s blithe to-the-manor-born line readings and asides make for a delicious Oscar pudding.Adam Sternbergh, Opinion Culture Editor“Murder on the Dancefloor” in “Saltburn.” Oscar for best song. I don’t care about eligibility rules. Make this happen.Vanessa Mobley, Op-Ed Editor Cornelia Channing, Editorial Assistant Yvonne Ashley Kouadjo, Op-Docs Producer Valerie Pavilonis, Editorial Assistant Rollin Hu, Researcher Jessica Grose, Writer Taylor Maggiacomo, Graphics Editor Madi Winfield, Editorial Assistant Jillian Weinberger, Senior Producer, Opinion Audio Annie-Rose Strasser, Executive Producer, Opinion Audio Christopher Orr, Editor Parker Richards, Staff Editor Anna Marks, Staff Editor Lindsay Crouse, Senior Staff Editor Patrick Healy, Deputy Editor, Opinion Adam Sternbergh, Opinion Culture EditorPHOTO:  (PHOTOGRAPH BY Amazon Studios FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)
